title_html: What you can learn for your startup from visiting Silicon Valley
html:
Homepage
Homepage

  • Get smarter at building startups

What you can learn for your startup from visiting Silicon Valley

Insights from my entrepreneurial pilgrimage to California

Daniel Kirch
Apr 27

San Francisco and Silicon Valley is for entrepreneurs what Florence is for art lovers or Hollywood for actors. It’s the place to be for decades when it comes to startups, digital technologies and venture capital.

As a VC-turned-entrepreneur I have of course read plenty of books and blogs about the “Valley”, watched documentaries, interviewed people that have lived or visited SF/SV as if they had access to sacred wisdom.

After years of analyzing that unique innovation ecosystem at the US-American west coast like a scientist watches cell growth under a microscope, I suddenly found myself in an Air France KLM Airbus from Paris to San Francisco and was on the way to my “Mecca”.

How did that happen?

In summer 2018, me and my co-founder Sven were selected to participate in a guided startup tour through San Francisco and Silicon Valley. This tour was organized and highly financially supported by the German-American chambers of commerce and the economic promotion department of North Rhine-Westphalia (NRW) to foster US expansions and international networking among entrepreneurs.

Only 12 promising early-stage startups from NRW were accepted. Our packed schedule included intercultural trainings, legal advice, entrepreneurial coaching, pitch training, investor discussions and representation of German technology in front of Valley professionals.

Highlights

We’ve met plenty of entrepreneurs & investors and visited several startups from different stages. A few highlights were:

Visit of Stanford University

  • as the source of highly qualified talent for the bay area and a hot spot for entrepreneurial education
  • Companies that were founded by Stanford grads include Alphabet, Coursera, Instagram, YouTube, SpaceX, Cisco, Netflix and many more.
  • There, we also met the Stuttgart born engineer and founder Andreas who graduated at Stanford with a PhD and founded a software company. Asked why he chose one of the most expensive regions for studying, he answered that studying in Germany would have been more expensive due to full scholarships talented students receive at Stanford. On top, the support you receive from the professors, Stanford Alumni network and associated investors is outstanding.

Tours through the LinkedIn, Google and SAP campus

  • The office culture of the big ones in Silicon Valley is unique. The buildings and surroundings are designed like a small village that contain everything to make an employee’s life as pleasant as possible, from gyms to restaurants to massage studios to laundries to shuttle services and bike rental stores and so on.
  • Clearly these costy perks are in the best interest of the company as employees don’t waste time on lunch breaks or in traffic jams and stay as productive as possible. I wonder, however, how this worry-free environment leads to a higher dependency of the employees on the company. Still, average retention period for staff at Facebook, Google and co. is supposedly around 1.5 years.

Meeting Mostafa, founder and CEO of HoloBuilder

  • Mostafa is an outstanding personality as he managed to flip his Aachen born startup into a Silicon Valley corporation including successful fundraising from SV venture capitalists.
  • Since the Valley is full of self-proclaimed prophets, coaches and consultants, it was refreshing to hear a more rational voice from his perspective on all those hyped topics.
  • The computer science grad from RWTH Aachen University now serves over 17.000 users from the construction space with a bi-continental developer and sales team. Impressive achievement!

Pitches in front of Silicon Valley investors

  • My pitches in front of Silicon Valley venture capitalists clearly were a special experience. Since SV investors supposedly see a lot more trends and business models through their deal flow and kind of know everything (“been there, done that”), they appear harder to convince.
  • In total, we received great feedback and input on our business model and could establish helpful connections for a future expansion to the US.
  • At one pitch event, the German Tech Match, we also met with a diplomatic delegation of State Minister for Economic Affairs, Digitization, Innovation and Energy Prof. Andreas Pinkwart and had the chance for a discussion on the innovation and funding challenges in Germany. Minister Pinkwart seems to have a straight-forward approach to make “his” province a great place for innovative companies.

Sightseeing

  • Of course, Sven and I also added some sightseeing activities in San Francisco, Las Vegas, Grand Canyon, Death Valley and Yosemite national park in order to get a holistic impression and free our minds. I will definitely come back to California and co. later and with more time.
  • While I don’t feel the urge to come back to Las Vegas (it appeared a bit trashy), I definitely fell in love with San Francisco as a very diverse city with beaches, old town, business district, hippie area, great restaurants and bars and sunshine! If it weren’t so expensive…

Learnings

Silicon Valley is not a place, it’s a mind set. That was an often perceived phrase. It stands for: people are in motion, network, help you but also think ‘what’s in for me’, strive, take risks, fail, restart, make it. This mind set includes a quite American-centric perspective with a touch of “What’s Europe?” which is underlined by the expectation of investors for every startup to move to the US if they expect funding.

However, walking through San Francisco, it appears there are two parallel universes mingling into a dualistic reality: the shiny startup-investor-innovation world with six digit entry salaries, office shuttles and free massage — and the “John Doe” world where “normal” people struggle at the poverty line while earning $100k due to crazy rental fees and living costs. A relatively high number of homeless people in SF is the result.

I’ve felt a lot of respect visiting companies whose product I use everyday (like Gmail or LinkedIn). At the same time I was pleased to see that also Silicon Valley giants deal with problems similar to those of small startups as correct translations or responsive mobile applications for instance. In the end, they also “put their pants on one leg at a time” and nobody is god-like.

Maybe Valley founders are not more ingenious than entrepreneurs from other places, but they doubtlessly get a much better access to capital as in the US there is five times more VC than in total Europe. And in the end, a mediocre idea with plenty of money in the back always wins over a fantastic concept with a lack of funding.

An important question remains: will Silicon Valley eventually overheat and decline in importance?

I believe, we — in Germany — have the technical competences, but we lack the amount of funding that can push innovation successfully into global markets. Looking at the US and China I currently don’t regard the European community being able to catch up with economic development overseas.

Conclusion

I’m very happy I finally stopped reading and talking about the Valley and eventually went and saw. A few ideas I had before had been confirmed, others were falsified and I gained new insights. I met impressive people, expanded my professional network to the benefit of our company and had fun.

For my future work at our AI startup Taxy.io I learned:

  • How to plan an expansion to the US and which VC to call
  • 9 hours of time difference are difficult when managing people and processes in both time zones, we better try the East Cost next time
  • The larger market and higher volume of venture capital comes with strong competition and high costs — a launch in the US is not per se ideal.
  • Germany offers a good balance between qualified HR, general costs, competitive landscape and access to capital. Starting here and later expand based on a stable fundament can make sense.
Applications for the next guided startup trip to Silicon Valley are open. Apply here.

Bonus:

Things that US-Americans don’t know how to make but also don’t care:

  • Wind-proof windows and doors
  • Shower armatures
  • Toilets
  • Include value added tax on their price tags

This story is published in The Startup, Medium’s largest entrepreneurship publication followed by +446,678 people.

Subscribe to receive our top stories here.
